ADJOURNMENT TO A LATER DAY MOTION


    The Chief Minister (Mr Lim Yew Hock): Mr Speaker, Sir, I rise to move, That at its rising today, the Assembly do stand adjourned to 3rd October, 1956.

    The Assistant Minister for Education (Inche Mohamed Sidik Bin Haji Abdul Hamid): I second the motion.

    Question put, and agreed to.

    Resolved,

    That at its rising today, the Assembly do stand adjourned to 3rd October,1956.

Column: 183

SUPPLEMENTARY PROVISION
(Sessional Paper No. Cmd. 43 of 1956)


    The Financial Secretary (Mr T. M. Hart): Mr Speaker, Sir, I have His Excellency's authority to move,

    That this Assembly resolves that the sum of $4,308,250 shall be supplied to the Government under the heads of expenditure and for the services specified in the Schedule contained in Sessional Paper No. Cmd. 43 of 1956.

    The Schedule contains the applications for supplementary vote which have accumulated since the last sitting of the Assembly. The applications amount to a total of about $4.3 millions, making a total of supplementary votes for this year of a little over $11 millions compared to the total of $27 millions on approximately the same date last year. I mention these figures because strenuous efforts have, in fact, been made to reduce Government expenditure in general and to limit the number of applications for supplementary vote in particular, and because criticisms have been levelled at the rate of Government expenditure both in and outside the Assembly. The fact of the matter is that applications for supplementary vote are inevitable and inescapable. It is impossible to foresee future needs when the estimates are framed. Needs arise which it would be shortsighted not to meet as soon as possible. The same situation arises in every type of organisation. It is not peculiar to Government alone. All we can do is to endeavour to limit supplementary applications to essential services. I do think we are making some progress in that direction.

    My first task is to report that, contrary to my undertaking at an earlier sitting of the Assembly, I have authorised two applications for funds for posts in anticipation of the approval of the Assembly. The first item is No.202. In this case, which is fully explained in the Schedule, it was represented to me by the Chief Justice through my hon. Friend the Attorney-General (Mr C. H. Butterfield) that the appointment of two additional Reporters was a matter of great urgency. In consequence, I approved the appointments with effect from the 1st of June.

Column: 184



    The second item is No. 238. In this case, it was represented to me by the Registrar of Malayan Statistics that the work of preparation for the field census tests proposed for the autumn of this year would be seriously held up if a stenographer were not appointed immediately to keep the minutes and act as Assistant Secretary to the Census Advisory Committee. After a very careful examination of the case submitted by the Registrar, I agreed to his request and authorised the creation of the post with effect from 10th July, 1956.

    I must also report that I have authorised a start to be made with the construction of hutted camp accommodation for the Singapore Battalion. It is desirable to raise the Battalion as soon as possible. The rate of recruitment depends to a certain extent on the availability of accommodation and it was therefore important to authorise the immediate commencement of work so that recruitment should not be held up.

    I am confident that it was in the interest of efficient administration that these authorities should be given. May I ask hon. Members to give covering approval?

    The various applications are explained in some detail in the Schedule but perhaps attention should be drawn to one or two items.

    A certain amount of publicity has been given to item 206, Cost of Telegrams, which, incidentally, has no direct connection with the Merdeka Mission. As means of communication develop, so one tends to use them. The habit has grown steadily over the years to communicate by telegram and radiogram. It saves much time and, I think, leads to greater efficiency and the speedier despatch of Government business. The practice is common not only in Government but also in business and other circles. Following this growing habit, Government expenditure on telegrams has tended to increase. Expenditure over the past five years has been as follows:1952, $12,000; 1953, $19,000; 1954, $23,000; 1955, $38,000; from 1st January to 9th August, 1956, $32,000. The considerable increase in 1956 over 1955

Column: 185

figures has been due, in the main, to increased communication on constitutional matters in the early part of this year. The original vote has now been expended and a supplement of $30,000 is asked for. This estimate was made in early June on the basis of average monthly expenditure in the first part of the year. There has been a slight falling off in expenditure since that date but the application has been kept to the same level in order to cover all possible contingencies in the future. There has been no extravagance in expenditure. Telegrams are despatched to all quarters of the globe and cover the multifarious business of government.

    Items 209 to 216 inclusive provide staff for the reorganisation of the Office of the Director of Personnel. This office has been seriously understaffed with the result that staff matters, staff negotiations and other similar matters have been considerably delayed. It is hoped that the reorganisation of the Branch now proposed will enable these matters to be speeded up.

    Item 218 seeks funds for ten Supernumerary posts to enable officers of the subordinate services to be tried out for promotion to the Administrative Service.

    Item 233 provides, inter alia, for a small car for a most courageous police officer who is completely paralysed from the waist down as a result of a wound incurred in a fight with a gunman.

    Items 220 to 232 inclusive seek provision for the initial steps required for the raising of the Singapore Battalion which is regarded as a matter of top priority.

    My colleagues and I shall be happy to amplify any of the explanations given in the Schedule. Sir, I beg to move.

    The Minister for Education (Mr Chew Swee Kee): I second the motion.

Committee of Supply


    Mr Speaker: Committee of Supply, what day?

    Mr Hart: Now, Sir.

    Motion and Schedule considered in Committee of Supply.

    The Chairman: Will hon. Members turn to page 38 where there is a summary of totals? I propose to call out the Heads and the amounts, and if any hon. Member wishes to speak on any Head, please say so.

    Head 3-

    Question proposed,

    That the sum of $38,700 for Head 3 stand part of the Schedule.

    Mr Lee Kuan Yew (Tanjong Pagar): Mr Chairman, Sir, I refer to item 195, Portrait of Sir John Nicoll. It appears from the explanation that the Friends of Singapore have sponsored this painting of Sir John Nicoll for a sum of $5,500. They have been able to collect only $2,100 and they expect or they are hoping that the City Council will bear half the balance and this Assembly will bear half the balance.

    Sir, we have no objections to people forming quaint societies like the Friends of Singapore amongst whose objects is the entertainment of past and present Governors and one of whose duties is to collect portraits of previous Governors. But having launched this undertaking, to come round to the Government and expect it to pay half the balance which they cannot raise is, to say the very least, just not good form. If they want kudos, as I am sure the President of the Friends of Singapore, who was once A.D.C. to the Governor, wants kudos for paying tribute to past Governors, then let them cough up and not come to this Assembly and ask for a vote.

    Mr R. Jumabhoy (Telok Ayer): Mr Chairman, Sir, I am a founder and life member of this Society. It is not a Society to entertain Governors or to give farewell parties and so on. The main object of this Society is to keep the relics of past and present Singapore. It is

Column: 187

possible that they might have entertained Governors, though personally since the last three years I have not attended any meeting - none whatsoever. This is what I want to point out to the Member for Tanjong Pagar.

    As to the principle whether or not this Society should come to the Government for meeting the balance of the cost of a portrait of a Governor and whether the Government should contribute towards it, that is a matter of opinion. I am not going to express any opinion.

    Mr Lee Choon Eng (Queenstown): Mr Chairman, Sir, I fully endorse the remarks of the Member for Tanjong Pagar. If the Friends of Singapore as a Society sponsored this portrait, it is up to them to bear the expense for it and if they cannot find the money themselves, then let them go to the public. A portrait of the Governor should be paid for by individual contributions from the public and not through this Assembly. Let them go to the public and ask for contributions. The contributions may be ten cents, a dollar or five dollars individually. That should be the right way rather than that this Assembly should be asked to vote for meeting the balance of the cost of this portrait. I will definitely not support this.

    Mr Hart: I am very sorry indeed, Sir, that this application for supplementary provision has met with the opposition which it has and I also much regret that the Friends of Singapore have come in for so much unjustifiable criticism.

    When the application was received, it was realised that it could well be argued that the Friends of Singapore, having voluntarily decided to embark on this project, should be allowed to complete the matter on their own. At the same time, it was considered that this was a somewhat unsympathetic attitude to adopt to an association which has done a great deal to arouse and maintain interest in the historical associations of Singapore, which many of my colleagues and I regard as a most important matter. It is right and pro-

Column: 188

per that Singapore should possess portraits of her distinguished citizens. It was a public-spirited move on the part of the Friends of Singapore to put in train the matter of a portrait of Sir John Nicoll, who by all standards is one of the most distinguished of Singapore's citizens. In these circumstances, it was considered that the Friends of Singapore deserved some assistance, particularly as they are finding great difficulty in raising funds. They have made public appeals and have other commitments in hand. It was therefore decided that Government would contribute half of the deficit if the City Council would contribute the other half. This, I am happy to say, the City Council has agreed to do and I now ask and I am sure I will have the support of the Assembly that this supplementary provision should be approved.

    Question put, and agreed to.

    The Chairman: The decision has been taken. I am very sorry. I did try and indicate that I would read out the Heads and the totals and that if any hon. Member wished to speak on any Head, he should let me know. When I reached Head 11, I understood from the indication of the Member for Tanjong Pagar that he wished to speak on Head 12.

    Mr Lee Kuan Yew: I beg your pardon, Mr Chairman.

    Mr Chairman: We are now on Head 12. I think it will be more satisfactory if I go item by item.

    Question again proposed.

    Mr Lee Choon Eng: Mr Chairman. Sir, I refer to item 219. We are asked to approve a supplementary vote for $59,860 for Local Government Elections. I wonder if the Hon. the Chief Secretary can inform this Assembly what has happened to the equipment for the previous elections. I think it is a waste of money if that equipment has been thrown away and for the Government to come again to this Assembly to ask for approval for the purchase of such equipment. The equipment can be retained for use for subsequent elections and I do not see why we should again approve another vote for such equipment.

    The Chief Secretary (Mr W. A. C. Goode): Sir, the answer is a simple one. As the hon. Member will have noticed from the White Paper and other policy statements made by the Government, it is now proposed not to limit Local Government elections to the City Council but to have Local Government elections throughout the whole island of

Column: 190

Singapore for the City Council and for four District Councils, involving a very great increase in the number of constituencies and the number of polling booths that will be required.

    Mr Lee Choon Eng: Am I to take it that this equipment is in addition to that for the previous elections?

    Mr Goode: Certainly.

    Question put, and agreed to.

    Question proposed,

    Mr Lee Kuan Yew: Sir, on item 241, International Bank Mission, can I enquire from the Hon. the Financial Secretary how they worked out the percentage which was to be borne by Singapore? How was the figure 25 per cent arrived at? Further, on the actual total itself - "One-half of salaries of the Members (the other half of salaries and other expenditure being charged against the Bank itself)" - how was that division between the Malayan Governments and the International Bank Mission arrived at?

Column: 191



    Mr Hart: Sir, it was appreciated when negotiations were made with the Bank for an economic survey of Malaya and Singapore that there might be difficulty in apportioning expenditure on the Bank Mission and it was then agreed between the two Governments that it would be left to Sir Louis Chick, the Head of the Mission, to recommend the apportionment of expenditure between the two territories on the basis of the work done and the value to the two territories of the Report. The proposals made by Sir Louis Chick have been accepted by both Governments.

    As regards the second question from my friend the Member for Tanjong Pagar, it is the custom of the Bank to pay all external travelling expenses of these Missions, to pay the salaries of their own employees who are posted to the Mission and half the salaries of the independent experts who are asked to join the Mission. The local Governments are responsible for all internal travelling expenses, accommodation and allowances in Malaya, and half the salaries of independent experts.

    Question put, and agreed to.

    Mr M. P. D. Nair (Seletar): Sir, on a point of clarification. May I ask the Hon. the Financial Secretary about the method adopted in advertising the tenders? As I see it, the cost has risen from 95 cents to $1.55.

    The Chairman: Item?

    Mr Nair: Item No. 243, Sir.It is a terrific increase and I would like to know the method of advertisement given to these tenders.

    Mr Hart: The method adopted for advertising for tenders for toddy is the usual one: notices are published in the Gazette. The great increase in price in the tender for this year is due - I am led to believe - to the activities of a political Party in the Toddy Workers Union.

Column: 192



    Mr Nair: In view of this increase, wi1l the Government reconsider the whole situation of the sale of toddy and see whether toddy sales can be abolished in Singapore?

    Mr Hart: I am not certain whether the Member for Seletar would agree that we should, by stopping the sale of toddy, drive the drinkers of toddy to even more potent spirits, but we will give consideration to the point he has raised.

    Mr R. Jumabhoy: Mr Chairman, Sir, may I ask whether the cost includes the removal of toddy shops from the places where the working people at present stay?

    Mr Hart: No, Sir. The tender price merely covers the tenderer's expenses.

    Mr Goh Tong Liang (Bukit Panjang): Mr Chairman, Sir, do I understand from the Hon. the Financial Secretary that toddy will be abolished very soon?

    Mr Hart: No, Sir.

    Mr Lee Kuan Yew: Who is fighting for Indian hopes!

    Question proposed,

    That the sum of $52,940 for Head 52 stand part of the Schedule.

    Mr Lee Kuan Yew: Will the Minister for Health explain why, within just about eight months since the Budget was debated, he is asking for three more Token Votes in items 261, 262 and 263? There was considerable debate during the Budget sittings on the question of medical expenditure being largely taken

Column: 193

up by emoluments. He assured us then that every particular claim put forward had been carefully screened. Now within a period of eight months he is putting in three token votes.

    The Minister for Health (Mr A. J. Braga): Sir, the explanation is given under items 261 and 262. Are those the items which my hon. Friend -

    Mr Lee Kuan Yew: Items 261, 262 and 263.

    Mr Braga: The explanations are there. Due to expansion, these posts are necessary. On item 262, the post is being filled by a Ear, Nose and Throat Specialist; and under item 263, these are filled by local medical practitioners who are necessary for the expansion of the services of that particular unit.

    Mr Lee Kuan Yew: Mr Chairman, Sir, that is most unsatisfactory. We can all read the notes and we know that $10 (Token) is to try and get two private medical practitioners. What we want is an explanation why these things could not have been foreseen when the Budget was debated.

    Mr Hart: Sir, these specialists have been employed for some time. It was envisaged, when the Estimates were drafted, that there would be savings on vacant posts for medical officers from which these specialists could be paid, but these posts have since been filled and it is now necessary to take a vote to enable the payment of these specialists to continue. That is why we ask for the token votes. It is a simple and normal procedure. That, I think, is the explanation which I have given and it is repeated in the Schedule.

    Mr Lee Kuan Yew: Mr Chairman, Sir, did I understand the Hon. the Financial Secretary to say that the reason why this thing was not claimed in the Budget was because, at the time, there were substantive appointments which were not filled and it was hoped that these people would be pushed into those substantive appointments?

Column: 194



    Mr Hart: From savings.

    Mr Lee Kuan Yew: Paid for? I do not understand how this Budget is being run. I thought that the Assembly is asked to pay against specific items for specific duties. Now we are informed that there could be some form of shuffling without the knowledge of this Assembly and that, although we are asked a certain vote for a particular post, the person who was holding the post at the time of the Budget debate was either just acting or temporary and it was hoped that when he moved up, those persons who were already then in the service could be pushed into those posts. But how does it work? I do not understand this.

    Mr Hart: The position is briefly this, Sir. The establishment of the Medical Department allows for a certain number of posts for medical officers and provision is entered against these posts - the provision which we think we will spend. Now, in the past, when we have been short of staff, doctors from outside the service have been engaged on my authority in a purely temporary capacity to do precisely the same job as medical officers were intended to do and have been paid from the vote for medical officers. That is quite proper. I give the authority for the employment of these people on a purely temporary month-to-month basis. In some cases, as in this case, they are merely employed on payment of a fee. What happened in this particular case was that the Minister for Health, in framing his estimates, thought that there would still be sufficient posts and savings available from which these temporary specialists who had come to the assistance of Government could be paid. It has now happened that, with recruitment from the University of Malaya medical school, these posts have been filled. It is therefore necessary to create a vote to pay the specialists. That is why we ask for these token votes. Sir, I cannot explain the matter more clearly. Perhaps -

Column: 195



    The Chairman: Order, please. I think possibly this is exactly the type of item which the Estimates Committee can look into in detail, but if the Member for Tanjong Pagar wishes to say something else, he can do so by all means.

    Mr Lee Kuan Yew: If I may, Mr Chairman?

    The Chairman: Yes, certainly.

    Mr Lee Kuan Yew: As I understand it now, the position is this. Take, for instance, this specialist under item 262. At the time of the Budget, there was somebody who was acting. It was thought then that savings could be made and there would be some particular Head under which this person, who was acting, could be paid. But since then somebody else has been recruited to fill that particular Head, and therefore this token vote is necessary to pay the person who, it was hoped, would be pushed under that vacant Head. But, in effect, what it means is this: at the time of the Budget, it was expected that only one person would be acting in that capacity, or would fill that particular post, but now two persons are doing the job - one, the person who filled the Head would be newly recruited; and, two, this person.

    Mr Hart: I agree with the Member for Tanjong Pagar that it would be desirable in the future if we have special provision in the Estimates for payments to specialists. I will bear that in mind in connection with the Estimates this year so that it will be clear to everybody that the honoraria or fees due to these specialists will be paid from a specific item under Personal Emoluments Subhead.

    Mr Lee Kuan Yew: That is elementary accounting.

    The Chairman: Order. The point I did make, I think, appears quite clearly in Standing Order 61(6) where it does state:

    "It shall be the duty of the (Estimates) Committee to examine any of the Estimates contained in the Schedules of Appropriation Bills and financial motions, to suggest the

Column: 196

form in which Estimates might be presented, and to report what economies consistent with the policy implied in the Estimates might be effected."

That is probably one of the items which the Estimates Committee could look into with advantage.

    Question put, and agreed to.

I think, in his enthusiasm for economy, my hon. Friend the Financial Secretary pruned all items of this sort down to the barest bones possible; but, in fact, in order to supervise the building programme, it has been necessary to get out and see the buildings and ensure that adequate supervision is given and therefore they have had to spend a bit more on travelling than was originally allowed for.

    Mr Lee Kuan Yew: In fact, this is, payment made to Government officers for travelling in the course of their duties, using their own cars to inspect Government works. It must be some fantastic rate at which they are being paid.

    Mr Goh Tong Liang: Mr Chairman, Sir, there is going to be a school in Woodlands but that school, I think, will not be ready by next year -

    The Chairman: Which item?

    Mr Goh Tong Liang: Item 302, Tiffin Sheds at 15 schools, on page 33. I was just wondering whether I can ask the Assembly to approve some more money for a temporary school in Woodlands. I had better make it quite clear, Mr Chairman, Sir. The other day, I spoke to the Assistant Minister for Education (Inche Mohamed Sidik Bin Haji Abdul Hamid) about providing a temporary school at the present time for the Malays in Woodlands. I was told that a public school will be ready by next year. At the present moment, there are a number of school children who have no schools to go to. [Interruption.] I thought we are going to ask money for -

    The Chairman: Order, please. We are now dealing with supplementary estimates and it is true that hon. Members can discuss the policy of Government on any item which appears on the supplementary votes. The item which has been indicated - item 302 - deals with Tiffin Sheds and I cannot see how the new school is relevant to that item.

Column: 198

But under item 278, I think there is provision for schools and perhaps the Member for Bukit Panjang could refer to that item and then discuss the omission to which he refers.

    Mr Goh Tong Liang: Yes, Mr Chairman, Sir, it should be this item, under Head D 48 Education. My intention is to ask for some more money as provision for building a temporary school, or at least to repair a shed which belongs to the Malayan Railways just now. What I want to know is whether provision can be made for a temporary school in Woodlands.

    The Minister for Education (Mr Chew Swee Kee): It would be uneconomical to build a school which might be completed at the end of the year and by that time we have another school. I do not understand what the Member for Bukit Panjang really wants.

    Mr Lee Kuan Yew: Votes.

    Mr Lim Choon Mong (Serangoon): Under item 278, Subhead 1, (ii) Holy Innocents' English School, the provision is for "New Extension Buildings, Furniture and Equipment and Science Apparatus, etc.". Can the Minister for Education let us know the number of laboratories this school is intending to build and the amount that is given for science apparatus?

    Mr Chew Swee Kee: I am sorry I cannot give all those details now but if the hon. Member will see me in my office, I will give him the details.

    Mr Lim Choon Mong: Sir, I ask this question on the science apparatus because I am connected with quite a number of schools and usually the grants given under this Heading are always small and it is quite impossible sometimes for schools to cater for teaching as well as for examination purposes and that is why I put this question.

    The Chairman: Order. I think hon. Members have probably forgotten Standing Order 69 (11) which reads:

    "On any question in the Committee of Supply debate shall be confined to the policy of the service for which the money is to be provided and shall not deal with the details of expenditure...",

Column: 199

    Last year, when the Development Estimates were under discussion I said that it was unlikely that the Public Works Department would be able to spend all the money voted in the various items in the Estimates. For a variety of reasons, work on some items would be held up and funds, and Public Works capacity, would be available for reallocation. If this proved to be the case, a switch programme of work should be introduced. Events have turned out as expected. It is now clear that there will be under-expenditure on some items and that the Public Works Department will be able to utilise the funds made available on other projects of importance.

    Schedule A lists the projects on which under-expenditure will occur. The total estimated under-expenditure is over $5 millions. The reasons for the under-expenditure are explained in the Schedule. I use the phrase "under-expenditure" advisedly. The word "savings" in this context apparently leads to misunderstanding. In the great majority of cases, the under-expenditure is merely deferred expenditure. There are, of course, a number of cases in which the under-expenditure is true saving. It will also be noted, not only in Schedule A but also in Schedule B, that the original estimate of cost has been revised in a number of cases. It is not easy for the Public Works Department to make an accurate estimate of the cost of a new project in advance of detailed planning and investigation. Many estimates have been made on the basis of a rough guide as to requirements from a department without plans and without knowledge of the site. It is only when plans and working drawings are made and when

Column: 202

quantities are taken and sites obtained and examined, that accurate estimates of cost can be made. Even these sometimes have to be revised. Changes of mind and ideas are not unknown. The surprising thing is not that the original estimates have to be revised but that they have to be revised so seldom and by so little. There are, however, one or two cases where the revised estimate has differed substantially from the original. One case is that of the Polytechnic. The original estimate of cost shown in the Estimates was $5.19 millions. This was based on the estimate made in the Gibson Report. It was taken as a rough guide until a more accurate estimate, based on plans, could be made. Of the $5.19 millions, $1.4 million was for equipment for the workshops, etc. No allowance was made for quarters and playing-fields. Plans were, drawn up by the architects commissioned for the job and it became clear that the sum of $3.8 millions would only go a part of the way towards meeting the cost of essential buildings. Later, these plans had to be revised in the light of advice obtained from the Advisory Council in London about the latest trends in technical college buildings. Only recently has it been possible to arrive at a reliable revised estimate of cost. This totals $11.4 millions and includes $7.5 millions for buildings and site preparation; $2½ millions for equipment and fittings; $1 million for staff quarters; and $500,000 for playing fields. The whole project has been reexamined in the light of this somewhat startling increase in cost. Plans prepared by the architects were examined with great care by the Director of Public Works and his architectural staff. The increase in cost is due in part to a substantial rise in the cost of structural steel and other building materials, and in part to changes in the plan. In the opinion of the Director of Public Works, the maximum economies have been practised in planning the buildings and there is little opportunity for further reduction. It has been decided, however, to refer the plans once more to the Advisory Committee on Building Costs to find out whether economies cannot be achieved on finishes.

    The Minister for Commerce and Industry (Mr J. M. Jumabhoy): Mr Speaker, I rise to move the motion standing in my name,

    That this Assembly, in accordance with subsection (2) of section 490 of the Merchant Shipping Ordinance (Chapter 207), resolves that the Merchant Shipping (Passenger Certificate Partial Survey Fees) (Amendment) Rules, 1956, published as Notification No. S 224 in the Gazette Supplement No. 55 dated 17th August, 1956, as contained in Sessional Paper No. S.L. 24 of 1956, be approved.

    Hon. Members will recall that, at the February sitting of this Assembly, I moved a similar motion to bring into force fees laid down for survey of parts of the machinery and equipment of ships.

    This motion, Sir, now seeks to enforce the Notification in the Gazette made on the 17th of August for fees laid down for partial surveys of the internal and external hulls of ships. It is anticipated that, in the near future, owners of passenger vessels registered in the United Kingdom may call upon us to survey

Column: 217

parts of the internal hull of a ship and we also expect them to call upon us to survey parts of the external hull of ships. This is the first time that such partial surveys will be recognised by the Ministry of Transport and Civil Aviation in the United Kingdom as going towards a full survey for a Passenger Safety Certificate to be issued by the United Kingdom Government. The opportunity has also been taken to see that these fees are fixed as a fair proportion of the full prescribed fees for the complete survey of hulls. Sir, I beg to move.

    Mr Goode: Sir, I second the motion. Question put, and agreed to.

    Resolved,

    That this Assembly, in accordance with subsection (2) of section 490 of the Merchant Shipping Ordinance (Chapter 207), resolves that the Merchant Shipping (Passenger Certificate Partial Survey Fees) (Amendment) Rules, 1956, published as Notification No. S 224 in the Gazette Supplement No. 55 dated 17th August, 1956, as contained in Sessional Paper No. S.L. 24 of 1956, be approved.

    The Assistant Minister for Local Government, Lands and Housing (Mr Tan Theng Chiang): Mr Speaker, Sir, I beg to move.

    That this Assembly, in accordance with subsection (2) of section 29 of the Registration of Deeds Ordinance (Chapter 255), resolves that the Registration of Deeds (Amendment) Rules, 1956, made by the Minister for Local Government, Lands and Housing on the 15th day of August, 1956, and published as Notification No. S 226 in the Gazette Supplement No. 55 of 17th August, 1956, as contained in Sessional Paper No. S.L. 25 of 1956, be approved.

    Sir, this is a straightforward matter. The Registration of Deeds (Amendment) Ordinance, 1956, which came into operation on the 20th of June, 1956, gave legal sanction to the inspection by the public of microfilm copies of deeds instead of original copies. The amendment of the Ordinance made necessary a few consequential amendments to the Registration of Deeds Rules, 1934, and the approval of this Assembly for these amendments is required under section
